All of student work follows the
same probability distribution. Not just some of it, not just
code, not just essays, not

just poems, not just
partial solutions, all of it follows the same probability
distribution called the Zipfian

distribution. And what that means, Zipfian
distributions on the ranking, like the popularity of
the most common solution

and the popularity of the
second most common solution. So if you take the
most common solution, this is how probable it is.

If you take the second
most common solution, this is how probable it is. And every single
educational data set that I ever got
my hands on, when

I looked at the log of
the rank and the log of the probabilities, you
always saw this straight line,

which led to this probability
density function, which comes from Zipf distribution. Whoa, that's cool. It's like the fattest
tailed distribution

you can ever imagine. By fat tailed
distribution, I mean, like, there's a lot of probability
far away from the mean.

So this is the most
probable solution. It has a probability like this. If I didn't do in

know what this thing looks like?  [LAUGHTER]

It just goes on forever. This tail is incredibly large. And it just basically says,

maybe there's one solution that

that really, really, really

cluster solutions,
